awd_titl_txt: OPUS: CRS -- A synthesis of the effects of biodiversity on plant, animal, and human health
awd_abstract_narration:
Connections between ecology and health have become more compelling and more urgent as society confronts increasingly rapid and widespread environmental challenges, including loss of biodiversity, globalization of species distributions, and changing weather patterns. These environmental changes often result in conditions suitable for local or global disease outbreaks. Once outbreaks are underway specialists in the ecology of infectious diseases are frequently asked to provide timely input, sometimes on disease systems that are not well known. One example is the recent rapid expansion of Zika virus in the Americas. However, appropriate data are often unavailable, for example because the species involved in transmission of an emerging pathogen are not known. What is needed is a better understanding of general principles underlying disease outbreaks and a toolkit of responses that slow disease spread. This project will produce synthesis papers describing aspects of ecological epidemiology and the relationship between biodiversity and health. These papers will be broadly accessible to students, scientists, and policy makers, and will help foster better-informed societal responses to disease outbreaks.  

One general principle that applies to many (but not all) disease systems is the dilution effect, in which ecological communities with higher species diversity have lower disease risk through a suite of well-understood mechanisms. Unfortunately, applications of the dilution effect to prediction and mitigation of infectious disease outbreaks are compromised by confusion about what it does and does not assert, and by misunderstandings of how it could be applied in policy and management. The project will synthesize current studies and provide an overview of the dilution effect, including the basic biology that underlies it. This synthesis paper be useful for students interested in health or ecology, and health professionals developing strategies for combating infectious diseases. A second synthesis will identify general principles linking biodiversity and health, which could guide future studies by providing more robust conceptual foundations than are currently available. This paper would be useful for disease ecologists and people in allied disciplines such as medical entomology or public health. In sum, these two products, will help move the field of disease ecology towards a more predictive future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project “OPUS: CRS -- A synthesis of the effects of biodiversity on plant, animal, and human health” was a multi-year synthesis project to explore the effects of biodiversity on the emergence and transmission of pathogens and parasites. The project’s goal was to articulate the state of knowledge of the field, focused on the publication of two papers.

The project was awarded just before the start of the COVID-19 pandemic, initially for a period of two years, and was granted to a single investigator. Within that time period, the project resulted in the two publications originally specified in the award. One of these, published in the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, explored how biodiversity, and its loss, affects the emergence and transmission of zoonotic pathogens, pathogens that are shared between humans and other animals. Based on a collation of evidence from a number of scientific studies, including results from the COVID-19 pandemic, the paper demonstrated that the loss of biodiversity typically results in an increase in risk for zoonotic diseases.

The second paper was a review of a phenomenon called a dilution effect, in which biodiversity protects against transmission of pathogens of humans, wildlife, and plants. The converse also holds: when biodiversity is lost from natural ecosystems, risk of exposure to pathogens typically increases. This paper, published with open access in the prestigious journal Ecology Letters was intended for a broad audience, including students interested in the state of knowledge in the field.

Because of disruptions caused by the pandemic, the project timeline was extended, and ultimately included two additional synthesis projects. The first of these, published in the preeminent scientific journal Science, was a review of the state of knowledge of rodent-borne diseases of humans. This paper showed that almost all pathogens that are shared between rodents and people come from rodents that live in close association with humans. These so-called “synanthropic” rodents represent just a small percentage of the more than 2,500 species of rodents around the world. The review also explored the state of knowledge of three important rodent-borne diseases – Lassa fever, Lyme disease, and plague.

The final synthesis project supported by this award is a book, currently under contract with Princeton University Press, targeted for a general audience, that explores the ecology of infectious diseases. The book underscores principles that apply across a number of infectious diseases, and which point to a suite of solutions we could, and should, be using to prevent future epidemics – but that we are currently not employing.
